citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult male Shih Tzu (ID# 23-041, DOB 4/23/23,) white with cream markings) had a large amount of watery discharge
that wetted the hair and skin around both eyes and a small amount of greenish discharge from the left eye. An opaque
area around the pupil was observed in the left eye. The dog was not squinting and the eyes did not appear painful. Eye
problems can progress rapidly, can become painful, and can result in loss of vision. The licensee must consult with a
veterinarian regarding diagnosis and treatment of this eye problem. Records of treatment must be made available to
APHIS officials.
To be corrected by October 31, 2023.

The last date of a hands on examination by a veterinarian was 20 March 2022. A hands on examination is important to
ensure the health of all dogs and the breeding condition of the dogs , The hands on examination identifies any potential
health issues so that they can be properly and addressed in a timely manner. The licensee must ensure that a complete
physical examination from head to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian is done not less than every 12 months.
Correction date: 27 December 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
KONSTANZE PLUMLEE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An adult male Shih Tzu (ID# 23-041, DOB 4/23/23,) white with cream markings) had a large amount of watery discharge 
that wetted the hair and skin around both eyes and a small amount of greenish discharge from the left eye. An opaque 
area around the pupil was observed in the left eye. The dog was not squinting and the eyes did not appear painful. Eye 
problems can progress rapidly, can become painful, and can result in loss of vision. The licensee must consult with a 
veterinarian regarding diagnosis and treatment of this eye problem. Records of treatment must be made available to 
APHIS officials. 
 
To be corrected by October 31, 2023. 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The last date of a hands on examination by a veterinarian was 20 March 2022. A hands on examination is important to 
ensure the health of all dogs and the breeding condition of the dogs , The hands on examination identifies any potential 
health issues so that they can be properly and addressed in a timely manner. The licensee must ensure that a complete 
physical examination from head to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian is done not less than every 12 months.  
 
Correction date: 27 December 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KONSTANZE PLUMLEE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
